metadata.goal: Discover NEW algorithms that BEAT state-of-the-art
metadata.key_insight: Asymptotic problems are <1% tractable. FINITE INSTANCES with unknown optimal are the real opportunity.
metadata.methodology: Curry-Howard correspondence: constructive existence proof → executable algorithm

asymptotic_problems.description: Problems where we'd try to beat SOTA for general n - mostly FANTASY for ATP (<1% success)
asymptotic_problems.grok_assessment: ATPs excel at VERIFICATION, not DISCOVERY. These require novel mathematical insights humans haven't found in decades.

problems.name: Matrix Multiplication
problems.why_hard: Unbounded search space. Requires novel algebraic identities.
problems.prior_ai_success: AlphaTensor (DeepMind) via RL, NOT theorem proving
problems.practical_impact: Would revolutionize ML training, linear algebra

problems.name: All-Pairs Shortest Paths (Dense, Small Integer Weights)
problems.gap: Upper ~O(n³/polylog) vs lower Ω(n²) - polynomial gap
problems.why_hard: SOTA uses algebraic methods - ATP search too open-ended

problems.name: Edit Distance (Levenshtein)
problems.why_hard: Discovery needs clever embeddings - fantasy for ATP

problems.name: Dynamic Orthogonal Range Queries (2D)
problems.upper_bound: O(log n log log n) amortized
problems.why_hard: Bounded to tree-based structures but still requires inventing new amortization tricks

problems.name: Subset Sum
problems.why_hard: Enormous combinatorial search space. Pure fantasy.

problems.name: Maximum Flow (Unit-Capacity Networks)
problems.gap: Upper ~O(n^{1.6}) for dense vs lower Ω(n^{1.33})
problems.why_hard: Requires novel potential functions or layering schemes

problems.name: Integer Multiplication
problems.lower_bound: Ω(n log n) in multitape TM
problems.gap: Tight asymptotically - only constant factors remain
problems.search_space: FFT-like transforms, polynomial evaluation (bounded to rings)
problems.why_best_of_bad: MOST TRACTABLE of asymptotic. Tight bounds mean constant-factor improvements. Strong Mathlib support.

finite_instances.description: TRACTABLE: Specific instances where optimal is UNKNOWN - real discovery potential (6-8 score)
finite_instances.grok_assessment: Computers have ALREADY found improvements in similar problems. Finite search space. SAT solvers succeeded on related instances.
key_properties: Optimal for that specific n is UNKNOWN

problems.name: Find 3rd smallest in 9 elements
problems.why_unknown: Optimal selection solved for small k/n but k=3, n=9 open
problems.prior_art: Computers found optimal median of 7 (10 comparisons)

problems.name: Merge two sorted lists (6 + 7 elements)
problems.why_unknown: Asymmetric merge cases not fully explored

problems.name: Find two largest in 12 elements
problems.why_unknown: Tournament structure for n=12 not fully explored
problems.lean_theorem: ∃ tree : MaxTwoTree 12, height tree ≤ 14 ∧ finds_max_two tree

problems.name: Sorting Network for n=11 (comparator count)
problems.why_unknown: SAT solvers got close for n=9-10 but n=11 search not exhausted
problems.prior_art: Computers found optimal for n=9 (25), n=10 (29)

problems.name: Sorting Network for n=13 (depth/parallel time)
problems.why_unknown: SAT improved n=11-12 depths but n=13 still open
problems.lean_theorem: ∃ net : SortingNetwork 13, depth net ≤ 8 ∧ sorts_all net

problems.name: Pancake Sorting for n=10 (worst-case flips)
problems.why_unknown: Known up to n=9 (12 flips), n=10 open
problems.historical_note: Bill Gates co-authored paper on this problem

problems.name: 4-bit Multiplier Boolean Circuit (gate count)
problems.why_unknown: Carry propagation complexity not fully optimized
problems.lean_theorem: ∃ circ : BoolCircuit (4×4→8), gates circ ≤ 42 ∧ computes_mult circ

already_submitted.description: Algorithm problems already submitted to Aristotle (re-deriving KNOWN optimal, not discovery)
already_submitted.note: These verify known algorithms, not discover new ones

result.min_comparisons_exact: PROVEN - finds minimum in n-1 comparisons
result.lesson: Typeclass instances must be explicit in structure definitions

ranked_for_submission.rationale: Smallest search space (~2^25), concrete decision tree, READY
Well-structured ladder networks, prior SAT success, READY
Classic problem, extensive prior work, READY
Larger search space, complex equivalence checking
